Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Universal Design of Inquiry-Based Middle and High School Science Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Federal Legislation has raised the expectations for students with disabilities within the general curriculum and assessment systems. Science education faces increased accountability for raising science achievement for a much more diverse population, while increasing the emphasis on learning that integrates higher-order thinking skills with content knowledge. Active science learning requires students to develop and use a number of complex skills including reading, observing, collecting and analyzing information, drawing conclusions and presenting findings. The principles of Universal Design for Learning (UDL) provide the flexibility of representation and the support of multiple means of expression and engagement to address this need. The Center for Applied Special Technologies (CAST) has pioneered the development of technology to differentiate instruction, mainly in literacy, for students with a wide range of abilities and disabilities. The University of Michigan and Education Development Centers are developing and testing comprehensive science curricula for the middle school and high school, respectively. They bring their joint expertise together to create heuristics for universally designed science materials for middle and high school instructional materials; to build an open source UDL Inquiry Science System (ISS) that enables science curricula to be transformed into digitally supported versions that incorporate UDL features; and to use the ISS to produce four UDL exemplars of chemistry and biology units from tested instructional materials and to evaluate the benefits of these exemplars for middle and high school students with and without learning disabilities. These materials support the development of the National Instructional Materials Accessibility Standards (NIMAS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Universal Design of Inquiry-Based Middle and High School Science Curriculum project developed web-based units from existing curricula, tested the materials in classrooms, and now provides three deliverables: 1) software others can use to create curricula, 2) guidelines for instantiating Universal Design for Learning principles in curricula, and 3) classroom-tested exemplars developed with the software and instantiating UDL principles. This collaborative project among CAST, Education Development Center (EDC), and the University of Michigan (UM) culminated in distribution via CAST’s website of three tools for developing web-based curricula.  

 

The UDL Curriculum Toolkit software system enables the authoring of e-curriculum using the tool as is—with built-in UDL supports for both individual and collaborative work—or reconfiguring it to meet other curricular goals. The IQWST exemplar (Investigating and Questioning our World through Science and Technology) showcases a middle school chemistry unit that addresses requirements of UDL as well as Common Core State Standards for Literacy in Science and Next Generation Science Standards. For example, a collaborative, interactive whiteboard feature enables teams or individual students to post models or explanations of the how and why of phenomena they investigate to the class whiteboard where student work can be shared, compared, discussed, critiqued, and revised. Along with UDL guidelines available on CAST’s website as enhanced through this work, the deliverables enable future research to build on this promising foundation. Developers can use the Toolkit and the interactive documents to design using the tool, to understand the rationale for decision-making, and to manipulate the exemplars. Materials are available here:

 

Toolkit:  http://udl-toolkit.cast.org/home

About the unit:  http://udl-toolkit.cast.org/p/applications/l2

Middle School (IQWST) Exemplar: http://udl-toolkit.cast.org/iqwst/login

 

In this design-based research project, we collected middle-school data (three teachers, three science classes each) to inform ongoing revision of each of the deliverables. Classroom observations and teacher interviews underscore the notion that providing teachers with UDL-enhanced materials does not ensure a UDL classroom. That is, in addition to learning the curriculum, the functionality of the program, and the use of technology, teachers are challenged to also implement instruction and develop a culture to support individual learners in a UDL manner. These complex interactions of teacher knowledge and skills render professional development and ongoing support imperative.

 

Data also included examination of individual features of the UDL-enhanced chemistry unit. We tested materials in urban classrooms wherein students had daily, one-to-one access to computers via a laptop cart. We found that students’ use of the program demonstrates the potential of each feature to support a wide range of students without bias for their performance levels. That is, both higher- and lower-performing students used the interactive supports in a similar way in terms of frequency. Those who used the reading and writing supports appropriately and more frequently outperformed students who used features inappropriately or less often, regardless of their pre-test performance level.
